Jesse Eisenberg is very effective in his performance as Mark Zuckerberg. But it is important to note that this performance is more a reflection of an idea of Zuckerberg than a reality. This is one of the reasons the movie works as well as it does. Aaron Sorkin's script is focused on the themes of isolation, ambition, greed and vengeance. Both had and David Fincher avoid bringing us into a fully realistic perspective regarding the mechanics of social media. This movie is a very abridged and slanted viewpoint of recent history. It ends up reducing FB and its founders' major purposes to 1. Asserting superiority and 2. To connect to love.

Fincher and Sorkin are masterful storytellers who smartly simplify a complex and important moment in the world of high-tech without sacrificing some of the major dynamics of the digital age that most interest them.

We live in a world where social networks are the biggest point of care for the population in different countries, the most famous of these since 2003 is "Facebook", some years ago the idea of a movie about this website was boring and a little complex to represent.

At the end of 2008 the writer and producer Aaron Sorkin announced that he had been writting an adaptation of the book "The Accidental Billionaires" by Ben Mezrich. After a few months the project was realized and ready to begin filming. 

The Social Network is the story about how in 2003, a 19-year-old Harvard University student Mark Zuckerberg, with the help of Eduardo Saverin, Chris Hughes and Dustin Moskovitz created a website called "thefacebook", where the people could made a personal profile to contact with other people. Also the film show us the personal feelings of the protagonists respect to the great change in their lives and the judgment in 2004 between Zuckerberg, Saverin and the Winklevoss brothers.

The director David Fincher is extraordinary, perhaps his best work so far, he is the man in charge here and knows how to make everything look good. Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross were the composers and they made the right music, I think is the best original score of 2010.

Jesse Eisenberg as Zuckerberg is excellent, demonstrating us that knows how to deal with a protagonist serious role, the rising star Andrew Garfield as Saverin is very good too but not better than the before mentioned, and the rest of the cast is just ok, Justin Timberlake stands out for being convincing in his character of Sean Parker or Roney Mara with just a few minutes on screen show us that she is a good actress.

The cinematography by Jeff Cronenweth and the edition by Kirk Baxter and Angus Wall are perfect in every way, the viewer can notice it from the first minute of the picture. 7/10

2010 has been a great year for films. There have been some truly groundbreaking works of art and films which have set the bar high for action and drama alike. Bear that in mind when I tell you that The Social Network outshines them all. This thinking may come heavily opposed but the fact is that you're not likely to see another film as perfectly cast, written, acted or directed for a long time, and it's been a long time since we have. Based upon the book The Accidental Billionaires: The Founding of Facebook, The Social Network revolves around the creation one of the biggest websites of all time: Facebook and its creator, Mark Zuckerberg. 

One of the greatest things about this film is Aaron Sorkin's script. Writer of A Few Good Men, The American President and the brilliant TV series The West Wing, Sorkin's incredibly rapid-fire script sparkles with a witty fury which dares you to keep up. Even West Wing watchers will find it difficult to catch every line without the occassional one flying over their heads. His conversations often go three different ways at once until they become suddenly, rivettingly intense and it's impossible to look away from the screen. It's been three years since we've seen one of Sorkin's scripts in action and it's fantastic to see that not only has he not lost his touch, he's getting better and better as the years go on. 

David Fincher has already established himself as an amazing director and in this film he shows himself to be an auteur of the highest calibre. His fantastic depth of field with every shot shows his incredible attention to detail and the way he manipulates his onscreen images in order to affect his audience. With an incredible CV of films including The Curious Case of Benjamin Button, Se7en and the monumental Fight Club, The Social Network is one of his finest yet. His use of shots shows an understanding of the audience which is lacking in many films and a talent missing in many of today's directors. His signature bronze murky colouring to every shot makes for startling comparisons between deposition scenes, smoky bars and booming night-clubs. 

The music is fantastic, a great blend of old school and new school tracks, as well as some well placed classical pieces which all come together brilliantly. The original score for the film is beautifully restrained, fitting perfectly in the brighter scenarios and the darker ones, a beautiful melancholy piece which you'll be humming all the way home from the cinema. 

And the acting. Cast to perfection, everyone on screen performs their role brilliantly. Jesse Eisenberg is amazing as Mark, speeding through his lines as if it's a race to the end of every sentence, it's as if he's been tailor made to Aaron Sorkin's needs. Finally being given the role he deserves and one which showcases his incredible talent, Eisenberg makes the most of his part, playing it perfectly. Armie Hammer is fantastic as the Winklevi as well as Max Minghella as Divya Narendra. The next Lisbeth Salander, Rooney Mara, is one of the standouts of the cast, magnetic in her limited screen time as Erica Albright. She has the steely determination and vulnerability perfect for her role and she rattles off her lines with a disarming realism. Mr. Multi-talent himself, Justin Timberlake, is incredible as Sean Parker, speaking with infinite charm and manipulation with equal parts comedy and smoothness. But it's Andrew Garfield who is the real standout here, which is saying something in a cast this fantastic. He is convincingly real in everything he does, from the very finest detail. He is perfectly restrained throughout the film, even though his temper comes to boil well before the incredible climax. His performance is perfectly judged and always convincing. With any hope it'll be his year for an Oscar nod. 

These parts by themselves are incredible but the way they all come together seamlessly and breathakingly is the reason that this film is being talked about so much. You'd be hard pressed to find a better combination of a cast, director and writer anywhere in film history, nor a film with such incredible content, perfect pacing and astonishing set pieces where the dialogue is more explosive than the Die Hard box set. I'm gonna say it right now: instant classic. It may be a big call but if any film is worthy of it, it's this one.

Every so often, a film comes along that takes a social phenomenon and uses it as a basis for a cinematic reflection on our times and a parable for greater universal themes. The Social Network is one of those films. The Social Network is a movie about the founding of Facebook by Harvard student Mark Zuckerberg and his friends and the lawsuits surrounding his social networking phenomenon. It is also a movie about friendships, trust, and betrayal. It is a movie about treating people with kindness and not running people over, driven by greed, for your own success. It is a film about intellectual property and what exactly constitutes an original idea. It is the story of a young man, incredibly intelligent and driven, who was able to create his own online empire and become the youngest billionaire in the world today. The film is not accurate as to the events that actually constituted the beginnings of Facebook. It was not meant to be. It is a movie based on a true story, and many of the things that happen in the film truly happened. But the characterizations, the motivations, are all part of the storytelling. This is a fictionalized, dramatized account of true events, made that way to not only make the movie more entertaining and captivating and to create tension and drama, but to make those broader social statements and themes ever more prevalent.

There is a scene near the end of David Fincher's The Social Network that succinctly sums up what the entire movie is about in one poignant moment. Eduardo Saverin, the former best friend of Mark Zuckerberg and CFO of Facebook, has just been pushed aside and manipulated by Zuckerberg and his fledgling company, having his holding interest in the company drop from 30% to .03%; his shares were the only ones diluted as new shareholders came into Facebook. Saverin is essentially no longer a part of Facebook, and, in anger and despair, has an emotionally charged personal exchange with Zuckerberg that digs into all of the personal issues the two of them have had throughout the entire film. Their jealousies and rivalries come to a head. Business and personal endeavors should always be separate, but when you and your best friend create a company worth billions of dollars, the lines can be easily blurred, and someone will inevitably be hurt or left behind.

This is really what The Social Network is about. The film is about the rivalry between two friends and about how power and manipulation eventually tear them apart. Mark Zuckerberg is made out to be a young man who excels online and in his business endeavors but who absolutely fails in his personal life. The opening credits sequence shows Zuckerberg, after being dumped by his girlfriend, running through the snowy streets of Harvard, past all of the huddled masses of people, into his dorm room to find the safety and companionship of his personal computer. At the end of the film, after Saverin leaves him after being kicked out of Facebook and Sean Parker, whom Zuckerberg idolized from first meeting, jeopardizes Facebook after being caught with cocaine at a party, we see Mark sitting in a chair by his computer, alone and sad, knowing that he is extremely successful, but also knowing that in the process of becoming so, he pushed everyone away that ever mattered to him.

In this way, The Social Network is both a warning against the perils of pushing friends aside for personal success in business and an observation on the direction that society nowadays is headed: that people are now feeling more comfortable in the digital world than in the real one, and would rather communicate with their "friends" online rather than be with them in person. Like Zuckerberg in the film, we as a society may be headed toward personal despair if we let ourselves be pulled completely into the digital world.

Fincher's film is masterfully constructed. Every aspect of it is intelligently thought-out and marvelously executed with a quality of craft that is remarkable. The script by Aaron Sorkin wonderfully bounces back and forth between court proceedings with actual events, retaining humor and heart amidst a story of revenge and personal failure and success. Sorkin's dialogue, delivered with rapid-fire conviction by the wonderful ensemble cast, is wordy and witty. There are sequences of great technical prowess in The Social Network. The whole movie looks beautiful. The music, acting, writing, directing, editing, cinematography, and everything else about the film is phenomenal. The Social Network is as entertaining and fast-paced as its wonderfully worded dialogue and as deep and exacting as its pure and exacting performances.

Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg comes across as a computer genius and jerk in this movie about the early days of the company. He's like Sheldon Cooper from "The Big Bang Theory" but without the self-awareness or the humour. The movie focuses on two lawsuits against Zuckerberg. One is launched by a couple of Harvard classmates who claim they had the Facebook idea first and hired Zuckerberg to program it, but he stole the idea and did it better. The other lawsuit is from Facebook's first CFO, who claimed he was deliberately pushed out of the company by Zuckerberg's new best friend, the self-promoting Shaun Parker, who invented Napster and mentored Facebook to stellar expansion and growth. In between legal depositions, we see flashbacks of Facebook's early days.

The film is anchored by strong performances from the entire cast. The film wisely focuses on the more dramatic business side of the company rather than on the geeky computer side. I expect some liberties have been taken for dramatic effect, so I'd be wary of treating this as history. It's more a character study of someone who encounters phenomenal success but still doesn't quite get why people still don't like him.

It's hard to think that a film about the creator of Facebook would be an all time classic and one of, if not, the best David Fincher film there is, but believe it. I remember the slack this film got prior to its release, one note excuses about  how bad a film it would be, "Why would anyone want to watch a film about facebook?" cried many people. Even to this day there are still people, who havent seen this movie and have no desire to because of the afformentioned. Let me tell you right here, that not only is this film a master class in film making, it is also a perfect example of kinetic and free flowing story telling during a long period of time. This film is about the relationship between Mark Zuckerberg and Eduardo Saveron, 2 friends a school, who after a bit of persuading by Mark, decide to create a website that could potentially make them big news within the school. Unknown to Saveron, the idea was based on identical twins, the Winkelvoss's and Divien Horrendra's idea for a web page called the Harvard Connection, which Mark used the basis off to create the hit page we all know and most likely have our own profiles on by now. The film documents the 2 ongoing court cases against Zuckerberg, while also documenting the rise of facebook and the deterioration of relationships around Zuckerberg as he becomes the worlds youngest billionaire. Sounds like a lot to cover in one movie? It is, but it is executed perfectly with a style and pace that just hurtles towards the finish line, giving you no time at all to breathe. You are constantly thrown between flashbacks, court cases and of the time situations continually. Not to mention the score, which ill touch on in a bit, which just keeps the whole thing bouncing until the final moments. The acting is beyond perfect, the cast of this film is perfect. Jesse Essenberg is brutally hilarious, smart and just the right amount of weird to pull of Zuckerberg, there are small blink and you will miss them moments where his attention is only on the job at hand his surroundings matter little to him, in one scene he runs through a mass of snow in flip flops in order to get back to  his dorm to add a line of code to facebook, its moments like this that make this film so addictive. Andrew Garfield is on fire and delivers the films most riveting performance, not only does he own the screen everytime hes on it, not only does he work amazingly well with Jesse as friends but he totally envelops the entire film, every scene he is in is just a wonder to watch. Justin Timberlake plays Sean Parker, the founder of Napster, who manages to sweep Zuckerberg off his feet and he does it with the style and panache that only Timberlake could deliver. Armie Hammer is excellent as both Winklevoss and Rooney Mara, for what time she has, is majestic as Zuckerbergs slight love interest. All of this would be polish were it not for Aaron Sorkins top notch script. Very few people do dialogue well but here, the script is brutal, whitty, challenging, intellectual and just so fast paced. It doesnt bog you down with needless shit, it hits it all perfectly and the actors deliver these lines just how they should be. This is testament to Finchers shooting style of around 50 takes per scene, at least. The look of the film is gorgeous, the colour is beyond glorious and the entire grade gives the film an eerie atmosphere. The real champion here though is the score. This film is genius without it, anything could have went over the top here and it wouldnt have lessend the experience. However Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross deliver a soundtrack that totally fires the film into stratospheric territory. No wonder they won an oscar for it, it adds an emotional weight to the entire piece that just has you completely hooked, body and soul. This film is my favourtie movie by Fincher, its smart, enjoyable, gorgeous, kinetic and dark. I  honestly cannot think of one bad thing to say about this movie, there is nothing bad about it. It works, on every level, buy, watch, talk about it, recommend it. This is a classic.

Story: Every age has its visionaries who leave, in the wake of their genius, a changed world--but rarely without a battle over exactly what happened and who was there at the moment of creation. "The Social Network" explores the moment at which Facebook was invented--through the warring perspectives of the super-smart young men who each claimed to be there at its inception. The movie moves from the halls of Harvard to the cubicles of Palo Alto to capture the heady early days of a culture-changing phenomenon in the making--and the way it both pulled a group of young revolutionaries together and then split them apart. In the midst of the chaos are Mark Zuckerberg (Jesse Eisenberg), the brilliant Harvard student who conceived a Web site; Eduardo Saverin (Andrew Garfield), once Zuckerberg's close friend, who provided the seed money for the fledgling company; Napster founder Sean Parker (Justin Timberlake), who brought Facebook to Silicon Valley's venture capitalists; and the Winklevoss twins (Armie Hammer and Josh Pence), the Harvard classmates who asserted that Zuckerberg stole their idea and then sued him for ownership of it. Each has his own narrative, his own version of the Facebook story in this multi-level portrait of 21st Century success--both the youthful fantasy of it and its finite realities as well.

At the outset I'll say The Social Network is a modern classic. David Fincher is a masterful director, and his attention to detail and well-known penchant for requiring 20 plus shots per take, have resulted in an incredibly polished product. Aaron Sorkin's screenplay is funny, moving, and tells a story that focuses on the character that created Facebook, as opposed to being a factual portrait of dates, events and people, leading to the popular sites launch and the legal aftermath that followed. The cast is superb, especially Jesse Eisenberg and Andrew Garfield , and I'll admit to being pleasantly surprised by how effective Justin Timberlake's contribution was.

A movie like The Social Network was inevitable. You don't create a web site with over 500 million users, and become a billionaire in just a few short years without drawing some attention to yourself. That kind of success must also warp public opinion both positively, and negatively. It attracts media attention, generates comments irregardless of any genuine research on the subject, and becomes fodder for others to profit from.

The movie is a fiction, loosely based on events that lead to the creation of the largest 'social network' the world currently knows. Ironically created by a character that by most people's estimations, probably suffers from Aspergers. The movie version of Mark Zuckerberg is awkward, arrogant and seemingly incapable of feeling empathy. He's also emotionally vulnerable, and despite the incredible popularity of his social project, finds himself alone, relying on his creation to make human connections.

The only minor issue I have with the film is with its insistence on labeling Zuckerberg a genius. Which likely stems from my understanding of the technology being used on the site since being a web developer by day allows me to put a roof over my head, and blog about all these wonderful movies at night! Facebook.com is a website, nothing more. Okay, it's a huge popular web site, that's clear, and it certainly was created by very clever programmers and engineers. But we're also talking about a website that was a variation of other social platforms already available at the time, and based on and idea that arguably wasn't entirely Zuckerberg's own. So when the movie juxtaposes Zuckerberg with Bill Gates, I can't decide if Sorkin is trying to say Gates is a genius, and Zuckerberg is the next generation. Or he's saying they are similar because history shows Bill Gates' success was less about genius level thinking, and more a mixture of talent, being in the right place at the right time, and business tenacity.

Movie Prep:

If you're curious about how Facebook got started, don't rely on this film for information. Watch it if you're in the mood for a great looking film that's well made, written and performed.

Best Format:

This is a gorgeously shot and edited film with an Oscar winning score by Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross, and if the opportunity to watch this at a theater near you opens up, certainly try to view this on the big screen. At home a HD viewing on a nice big TV is recommended. Watching this on anything smaller will ruin the impact of the film.

Best Moment:

I've watched The Social Network several times now, and I've also watched Citizen Kane a few times too. My favorite moment in The Social Network is right up there with the classic opening shot of Citizen Kane, when Kane drops the snow-globe and we hear the word 'Rosebud.'

At the end of The Social Network, Mark Zuckerberg, the man with over 500 million people using his website, is all alone in front of his laptop. He searches for a girl he used to date, Erica Albright (Rooney Mara) and sends her a 'friend request.' He then sits there, repeatedly refreshing the web page to see if she's responded as the camera slowly zooms in. As Kane's last word speaks of a lost childhood, Zuckerberg's last action of the film comments on his inability to make a proper human connection.

The Social Network is an intelligent Drama directed masterfully by David Fincher. The film follows the story of Mark Zuckerberg, the creator of Facebook, who is played by Jesse Eisenberg who gives a very powerful performance. The film is brilliantly scripted and full of smart and interesting characters. The film has a compelling story that revolves around greed and it shows us that by becoming famous you can make enemies of the people you hold most dear.
In what other movie are you going to get to see London Tipton go down on Spider-Man? Jesse Eisenberg is perfectly cast as Mark Zuckerberg and the entire film is fantastic all-around.

I didnâ(TM)t think that the creation of Facebook really had enough to constitute creating a biographical film, but considering the many Academy Award nominations it received I had to witness it.
 
Usually, films which are as talkative as The Social Network tend to bore me, and considering the way that the film just rushes through it all at an exceptionally energetically fuelled fast pace. I was actually very impressed with The Social Network because it constantly kept me interested. Although the story is about college boys setting up a social network and the resulting conflicts that it ends up causing didnâ(TM)t sound too interesting to me on the surface and the fact that the film did stretch itself on for a while with some repetitive moments, The Social Network ended up impressing me at just how well it could tell a story because it put a lot of depth and tension into the tale and rendered it a meaningful and compelling piece of cinema.
There was no way for me to tell that there was so much depth behind the creation of Facebook, but The Social Network did it excellently. Through the power of an ambitious script which is intelligent and dramatic with a nice touch of comedy, The Social Network manages to intelligently convey to audiences how the creation of a revolutionary website came to fruition and how it affected everybody involved. The language is impressive because although it makes use of a lot of complex terms and rushes by throughout the film, audiences are easily able to understand everything that the characters are talking about and just what the meaning is of what they are saying. The ambitious scope that Aaron Sorkin goes for in his script manages to capture many years of development into the creation of Facebook and also brings the characters to life in an excellent dramatization and re-enactment of everything that is happening, and under the fierce direction of David Fincher it manages to reach incredible heights of success. Frankly, I was very impressed with just how much The Social Network was able to offer in terms of storytelling because of the limited concept behind it, and the fact that it held my interest with intense, fast paced storytelling was just exceptional. The Social Network is one of those films which leaves a viewer examining just what kind of strength a film can use to tell a story when the creators have a true passion for it, and although it does deviate from the real life events as does every film biopic, it manages to create consistently interesting and complex themes and concepts to go with its characters, rendering it a very good film.
But the reason that The Social Network stands so tall is because of the fact that the cast in the film manage to take full advantage of the characters presented to them and turn the film into an unforgettable front for the talents of a large and versatile list of actors.
Jesse Eisenberg is perfect for the role of Mark Zuckerberg because he captures the neuroticism of the character by contributing his own. Although a character like his tends to usually be a nerdy archetype who talks himself around and out of complex situations, the role of the character Mark Zuckerberg is a lot more complex than anybody could have honestly expected. The man is a genius, and with Jesse Eisenbergâ(TM)s talent for swift and powerful line delivery, he takes on the role and gives it his maximum skill as an actor which is thoroughly impressive. Jesse Eisenberg captures the relentless dedication to achievement which would turn Mark Zuckerberg into the worldâ(TM)s youngest billionaire with extraordinary ease, and it combines all of his best talents as an actor which manifests itself into his best performance to date. Jesse Eisenberg gives a meaningful and compelling portrayal behind the man that created Facebook, and he carries the entire film from start to finish. 
Andrew Garfield gives a breakthrough performance in The Social Network. The most important aspects of his performance come from the way that he interacts with Jesse Eisenberg as the relationships between their characters Eduardo Saverin and Mark Zuckerberg because the chemistry they share manifests itself into a seriously tense conflict.  The scenes they share together are powerful, and Andrew Garfield shows off the kind of tense emotional strength he carries as an actor when he sees fit.  Andrew Garfieldâ(TM)s performance in The Social Network is impressive, and his interactions with the many surrounding cast members reveal what his natural talents are all about.
Justin Timberlake is an actor that I find myself gradually growing to like, and I donâ(TM)t think Iâ(TM)ve seen him give a better performance than his role as Sean Parker in The Social Network. The thing is that his character is very confident and essentially fearless in his goal to be the best, and the kind of determination that Justin Timberlake channels into the role is just great. Justin Timberlake projects a lot of natural charisma in his role as Sean Parker and capitalises on the opportunity very well, guiding himself to an impressive performance and his chemistry with Jesse Eisenberg has them challenging the wits of each other very well.
Armie Hammer also makes a great dual role as Cameron and Tyler Winklevoss because he seamlessly creates two characters which leaves the audience easily believing that the two of them are actually portrayed by separate actors. Using visual techniques, David Fincher is able to create the illusion of two characters, and through his natural acting charisma Armie Hammer manages to easily portray the two of them. He created a chemistry with himself which is challenging to do, but he does it very easily, and the determined nature of his line delivery and simple sense of strength that he supplies to the role prove to be more than enough for him to give a successful performance in The Social Network.
Radisha Jones also makes a memorable supporting effort.

So although it doesn't feel 100% genuine and it does sometimes have a slight feeling of repetition, The Social Network is a powerfully acted and well scripted story which breathes depth into the complicated events regarding the creation of one of the world's most recognised websites.

With one of the most spectacular screenplays in modern memory and featuring top-notch performances from Eisenberg, Timberlake, Garfield and pretty much everyone else, The Social Network, in the competent hands of David Fincher, is a modern entrepreneurial masterpiece. Its sheer brilliance easily overcomes the film's only minor speed bump - its liberty with real life.

David Fincher always manages to direct with such flair, verve and energy and it's never been more apparent with The Social Network, in my view he's the best director working just now. Obviously, like any film that's loosely based on true events, liberties are taken with the events and the characters. Whether you're on Zuckerberg's side or not. Whether you feel this is a hatchet job, the filmmakers didn't hammer Zuckerberg hard enough, or you just don't give a damn about Facebook in general, this is still a smart, compelling, relevant film that had me hooked from start to finish just as much as that damn Angry Birds Friends Facebook app gets me every week. That a story about a fairly unlikeable man who created a website could be turned into such a fascinating film is evidence enough to the talent that flows through director David Fincher, writer Aaron Sorkin and the talented cast at hand.

I have no idea how to start this review of The Social Network. What can you say about a movie that is so entirely well made? So entirely entertaining? So entirely impressive? I don't know ... I mean, other than the obvious. Looking at The Social Network as a movie (and a piece of entertainment), there's nothing bad you can say about it. What holds the movie back, in my opinion, is the lack of "true" in this "true story." I know the liberties that director David Fincher and screenwriter Aaron Sorkin take make the movie more cinematic and interesting; but that still doesn't change the fact that much of this movie is not, in fact ... fact.

"The Facebook Movie" as it's too often called, chronicles the rise of genius Harvard student, Mark Zuckerberg, creator of the Book of Faces. After gaining the attention of two rich, athletic,  and smart twins, Mark is tasked with creating a website. The Winklevoss twins want Mark to create a website Harvard Connection, a social network/dating site exclusive to Harvard students. Zuckerberg takes this seed of an idea, and grows it into Thefacebook. He partners up with his best (and only) friend, Eduardo. The site is launched, and it takes off. It becomes popular, incredibly so. But then greed and success begin to poison things. Lawsuits ensue, and Mark is put through the ringer.

The incidents that are shown in the movie are mostly true, but almost everything around that seems padded, if not entirely false. Real-world Zuckerberg isn't as much of a condescending jerk as he's portrayed in the movie. Justin Timberlake's performance as Sean Parker is supposedly exactly opposite of how Parker is in real life. Andrew Garfield's character, Eduardo Saverin, said of the movie, "the movie was clearly intended to be entertainment and not a fact-based documentary." Screenwriter Aaron Sorkin even said, "I don't want my fidelity to be to the truth; I want it to be to storytelling." 

Which isn't necessarily a bad thing. Don't get me wrong, I enjoy watching Justin Timberlake play an arrogant know-it-all. I relish every opportunity to see Jessie Eisenberg play a condescending genius. I want Andrew Garfield to be able to give a dramatic performance, even if the events aren't entirely true. To take The Social Network as a piece of entertainment, I want and enjoy everything this movie has to offer. But as a piece of supposed "truth," I am just a bit put off by the liberties the filmmakers take. But just a bit, as you can tell by the fact that I'm giving this movie 10% less than a perfect score. 

The script, other than the fact that it doesn't follow the true story very well, is truly excellent! The dialogue crackles with intelligence and wit! This fictionalized take on Mark Zuckerberg is really fun. Eisenberg does so well with the role, because it specifically plays into his strengths.

And why not take this time to talk about the acting. Jessie Eisenberg is such a talented guy. He can deliver these lines with so much humor, when its needed. He can also portray real, genuine drama. He received a well deserved Academy Award nomination for this role. This is the kind of transformative movie that can change "comedy nerd version infinity" into "Jessie Eisenberg, the actor." And now, he's tackling the massive challenge of playing a non-conventional version of Lex Luther in Batman vs. Superman. I'm excited, more power to him!

Matching Eisenberg talent for talent is Spider-Man himself, Andrew Garfield. He gives the very best performance of the movie (which is saying a whole lot) as Eduardo. Garfield is terrific! He makes the whole thing so much more human. Eduardo is definitely the most "I'm rooting for this guy" character in the movie. Because he isn't a jerk. He doesn't exploit other people. He is a man of character. The scene where Eduardo verbally assaults Mark after finding out that he was cheated out of all his stock in the company is especially phenomenal. It's a truly superb performance! 

The supporting cast honestly doesn't have a weak link. Justin Timberlake brings it as Sean Parker. Even if the real life character was totally different, Timberlake's performance is still stellar! I does feel just a bit like Justin Timberlake playing ... Justin Timberlake. But that's fine! Armie Hammer is very strong as the Winklevoss twins. I really hope The Lone Ranger doesn't torpedo his career. Also watch for Rooney Mara in a small, but essential part.

David Fincher's direction is just astounding. There isn't a single negative thing to say about 95% of the production. The top-notch editing and cinematography are big standouts.

But the 5% of the production side of things that I didn't like is the musical score by Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross. I guess it kind of, sort of fits the movie decently. Still, the same sound could have been achieved to much better effect by Cliff Martinez. The Reznor and Ross score is grating and almost unbearable outside of the film. I usually listen to the musical score of a movie when I'm reviewing said movie, but I just couldn't with this one. I tried, but the music is so obnoxious, I found my writing was greatly suffering from listening to such intolerable rubbish. And the most infuriating thing about it? This simplistic and unpleasant score won the Academy Award over John Powell's flawless score to How To Train Your Dragon.

Overall, minus the horrible score and the bit-too-fictionalized story, you have one of the "coolest" movies you'll ever see! The story is never, ever boring. The comedy and drama play out naturally and in satisfying amounts. And the movie is anchored by two outstanding performances by Eisenberg and Garfield. What David Fincher was able to accomplish with The Social Network is possibly the definitive movie for this generation. Generation Y. Our generation.

The late, great JW famously referred to The Social Network as one of the worst movies ever made. Well, it just goes to show you how much of a moron JW was. The Social Network, the most critically-acclaimed film from one of my favorite directors (David Fincher), isn't quite the rip-roaring ride of action, drama, grit, and intrigue that one would expect from the director of Fight Club and Seven, but it's still one of the best dramatizations of a mundane world event ever conceived. It takes real talent to make a website being created entertaining, but hell, I was enthralled through virtually the whole thing.

The Social Network is the story of how Mark "Fuckerberg" Zuckerberg ripped off the Winklevoss twins and created Facebook, the greatest disservice to American culture since the invention of communism. One would think that such a detestable main character, coupled with a putrid story, would result in a mess of a film. Well, that couldn't be further from the truth. Fincher is an expert at working with antiheroes, as he's proven before with the charismatic yet insane Tyler Durden. Here he isn't allowed to go to town as much as one would like, but he still manages to make Zuckerberg (played by a perfectly cast Jesse Eisenberg) both charismatic and cunning, two traits that the real-life Fuckerberg lacks. Using his geeky charm and warped world view, the character is able to reel the audience in in a Richard III, Frank Underwood, or Walter White kind of way, forcing us to participate in the enjoyment of his misdeeds and excess, and thusly making us accomplices to his crimes of intellectual property theft. Okay, it's not a perfect comparison, because... well... this guy made a website and Walter White cooked meth to provide for his family. Still, you get the point.

Although Facebook is absolutely evil, the concept is a sound business plan. And the audience already knows the outcome of these events, which makes the scenes in which Zuckerberg steals the idea all the more motivating and enjoyable. Still, the movie never quite breaks past the bonds of "people just talking," and doesn't quite strike a chord on a more emotional level than that. Sure, plagiarism is bad. We get it. You need to have a more interesting message than that if you expect people to keep their asses planted firmly in their seats for two hours. Still, the cast charms, and the story itself is such an amazingly ludicrous-- not to mention true-- tale that it's impossible not to be sucked in.

Final Score for The Social Network: 7/10 stars. It's not quite on-par with Fincher's more over-the-top work, but instead of relying on visceral thrills and pulse-pounding tension, this movie relies on its ingenious, David Mamet-style script and strong performances to keep the pressure building, all the while showcasing an antihero with a woefully misguided moral compass who, against all odds, manages to constantly stay one step ahead of his detractors. In fact, that might be the message of The Social Network right there: In the business world, you don't have to be liked. You don't even have to be tolerated. You just have to win. And as much as I hate his guts, Mark Fuckerberg has won fair and square, making buttloads of cash off of "his" idea and becoming one of the youngest billionaires of all time. No, he is not a good person. But yes, this is a good story.

Imagine a world with no Facebook. It's pretty unbelievable isn't it. It has made such an impact on contemporary society that for most people, it becomes a necessity. The point of the social networking site is to see what your "friends" are doing and bring each other closer together. After watching this film, I found that idea to be pretty ironic.

The Social Network was based on a novel by Ben Mezrich entitled "The Accidental Billionaires". The book was adapted by screenwriter, Aaron Sorkin, who has made a name for himself with works like A Few Good Men, The West Wing, and Moneyball. Currently this is the only product that I have seen from him, so I cannot comment on the trademarks and styles that he commonly employs in his films. I can definitely say that he has written a wonderful script. The Social Network touches on the themes of friendship, betrayal, social acceptance, pride, and success. The film could have focused on the much bigger idea, the origin, success and impact of Facebook. Instead Sorkin wanted the film to be more personal and intimate. I cannot say how much of the film is accurate to reality or to the source material, as I am ignorant of Facebook or Zuckerberg's story. The Social Network focuses on it's creator, Mark Zuckerberg. It details about the beginnings of the product , and what's surprising about it was that it didn't take the capitalist approach that is commonly found in most success stories. Instead it creates all of this psychological and emotional issues with our protagonist and have that be the fuel for success. It never was about gaining the most profits. It was about being cool; It was about fixing the reputation that he made for himself; It was about being better. Facebook was a symbol of a boy's frustration and the filling of a void, through the gain of "friends", that was emptied from a collapsed relationship. Sorkin wanted Facebook to be the reason for Zuckerberg's failure in his personal life, and the road towards this self-destruction made the tale all the more interesting. We always assume that this man must be the luckiest and happiest person in the world because he gained so much wealth from it, but we never really considered what he lost from it. Sorkin doesn't give us an ending that might please us, but if we think about it, why would he? The ending of Facebook and Zuckerberg has yet to be written and it's impact is all around us. If there was something in Sorkin's writing that I would praise the most, it's his ability to write great dialogue. It fills the scene with lightning speed and doesn't sacrifice intensity and weight with it. The banter alone at the start of the film is evident enough of how great his writing is, it introduces and defines the character in a matter of minutes, letting the film move along and focus on it's story.

The film was directed by David Fincher, who I consider to be one of the greatest directors of the 21st century, though some of his best work was found in the last decade before the turn of the century. The Social Network was a big surprise for me, as a few of Fincher's films have addressed the current state of society and the subject of this film would have been a great example in exploring that concept again. Instead he takes a left turn, stripping all of that and creating something small and private. Fincher has been known to make films with a dark atmosphere, aside from The Curious Case of Benjamin Button. I think he likes to explore the dark and untouched layers of humans, because maybe it leads to a much more tense and interesting story, or maybe he just wants to be unique, or maybe he resents the false illusion of happiness in people's lives. On my previous review, I accused this film of being light and more happy, but the more I watched it, the more I started to peel and find the layers in the film's characters and saw something that was more darker and sorrowful than what was projected. Fincher has taken a product that is generally known for bringing people closer together, and viewing it as a source of a person's self destruction. This is the reason why I love Fincher's work because he always creates something that we don't really expect, leaving us shocked and surprised until the credits roll. Though the film has it's dark moments, Fincher doesn't forget the essence of Facebook, youth. The film feels youthful, it's slick and cool, and moves at an intensely fast pace. Fincher gives this film so much energy that it makes Sorkin's script come alive, and it also makes for an entertaining film. The film was able to give off this aura of intellect but it never goes to a point of condescension or pretension, allowing the film to retain this accessibility, which has made me come back to it time and time again.

Jeff Cronenweth has done three films with David Fincher; Fight Club, The Social Network and The Girl With The Dragon Tattoo. I felt this was his most safest compared to the three. It's very focused on capturing the drama rather than being something different and off the wall. The title sequence, where Zuckerberg runs through the campus of Harvard and the final shot that slowly zooms in on Zuckerberg's face, was shot beautifully. His sad facial expression as the last statement is placed on screen before the credits, "Zuckerberg is the youngest billionaire in the world", and along with the intimate and slow zooming photography just expresses the burden that his own creation has caused. Cronenweth, especially in the legal side of things, create this golden aura. Does that symbolise the fight for greed with these characters? Does the room radiate success, I am not quite sure, but maybe as I watch the film more, it would start to become more clear to me. The film may not reach the darkness that is found on The Girl With The Dragon Tattoo or Fight Club, but it is still present here in correlation with the pessimistic depth this film contains. Cronenweth's work on this one is not something that I would remember as much but it does apply appropriately to the drama.

Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross' work on this film is definitely a plus for me. There was a composition that plays after Zuckerberg's break up with Albright (Rooney Mara) that combines razor violins that haunts the track with a piano that is feels so simple and delicate. It not only sets the film up to a sad start but it also enhances certain moments in the film that make the drama even more dramatic, particularly the scene where Garfield walks up to Zuckerberg and smashes his computer and having an argument. That particular scene is the final cut in their relationship that destroyed their friendship, the ultimate betrayal. That particular composition is used in scenes where Zuckerberg has lost someone important in his life. It is heartbreaking to listen to.

Both Garfield and Eisenberg gave their most emotionally driven performances I have ever seen. I don't know if it's accurate or not but it doesn't matter as long as their performance drives the story forward and that they are believable in their roles. I felt that Garfield should have been nominated for a supporting actor at the Academy Award as his performance dominates everyone else in this film. Justin Timberlake in this film plays Sean Parker efficiently, he knows how to convincingly act like a jackass. It was a character though I did not like when on screen as I felt he was written to unlikable but I guess that was the point. Rooney Mara's character is a crucial piece but she was a little underused in this film, all is well though cause she has a leading role in Fincher's next film. This film definitely proved that both Garfield and Eisenberg has acting chops and are Oscar worthy.

It is too soon to say whether or not this film's significance and power will continue to radiate in the years to come. But I wouldn't be surprised if this film would be end up becoming a classic in the near future.

Maybe not understanding all the programming and math involved in the technical side of the project makes me feel like an idiot? I have no idea what any of equations or algorithms mean, or how to write script. Maybe I'm a little jealous because I never got to go to college parties as glamorous as the ones in this film? Or maybe the problem is that the subject matter it just so banal that despite the quality of the production, this film is lost on me? I have a problem with this film that is so full of maybes. And yet for all its weaknesses, it won three Oscars, albeit one of them was for Baxter and Wall's editing, which is superb. Both editors have worked on numerous Fincher productions. 

None of the actors are convincing at portraying the real people they are supposed represent. Maybe that's the point? They are attempting to play versions of Zuckerberg and Co. that seem more interesting than the real, live versions. I guess I see the reasoning behind this. As activities, creating companies, programming computers, or writing software, no matter how profound, aren't exactly as riveting as invading Bin Laden's compound, or smuggling blood diamonds out of Liberia. Still, I am no fan of Jesse Eisenberg. His success is baffling to me. He was for a while a Michael Cera impersonation gone wrong, now, whatever he is, he does it well. He sells tons of tickets... but none of them are to me. The best part about this film is that it has Rooney Mara, briefly. Later she becomes Lisbeth in Dragon Tattoo.

The most interesting thing about this film is simply that it exists and was so successful. Rather, that a production company actually paid David Fincher to try and create a full-on thriller packed with betraying, greedy, snarky little boys either getting their way, or losing millions of dollars. Poor babies. Even if in the end Zuckerberg did create something monumental, so what. It's just a monument to a monument. What does any of this represent? How does any of this change the world? It's not like Facebook has cured any sick people or stopped any wars. It's arguably even created a recent few (of both).

The movie seems to be the story of how Mark Zuckerberg founded Facebook while abandoning his friend and using others to achieve success, and doing it all while pretending he doesn't care about money or popularity. However, this movie is based off the book "The Accidental Billionaires" by Ben Mezrich, who apparently wrote the supposed-biography from the point of view of the people who seem to have good reason to dislike Zuckerberg as they are some of the people that floundered when Zuckerberg flourished. I'm not sure how much is actually believable, but I do like the roundness of the story. At the beginning when Zuckerberg is dumped, his ex-girlfriend tells him that girls will dislike him because he is an asshole. At the end of the story, one of the lawyers tells him that he isn't an asshole, he is only trying to be one. It's an interesting thought to process, as during the movie we are wondering if he really is the jerk he plays, or if he is just playing a jerk because that is the thing to do? While this isn't a favorite movie of mine, and isn't one I would typically make time to watch(was for a school assignment), it was decently good and an interesting take on one of the most popular things to hit the world.

When I first heard that a film was being made about the creation of Facebook, I was extremely skeptical of how it would turn out. I'm not a Facebook user, so the idea of a movie about it and its creator Mark Zuckerberg wouldn't appeal to me, and biopics don't really have a strong reputation in the film industry, particularly when it comes to telling the truth. With the film gaining a massive popularity, with its Oscar buzz and its inspiration to many young entrepreneurs, while I was still skeptical of what I would think of the film, it made my skepticism of the film a little lighter. After finally getting my experience of this massively acclaimed film, my initial thoughts of the film actually happened; while I do not understand the power of Facebook nor rave massive praise like almost every single critic in the country, I do admit that The Social Network is still decently made, and is still worth anyone's time.

In 2003, Harvard undergrad and computer genius Mark Zuckerberg (Jesse Eisenberg) came up with the idea of a social-media site that could change society forever. After a few tweaks, Zuckerberg's "Facebook" site becomes one of the most successful websites of all-time, but Zuckerberg's newfound fame comes at a price. His personal life becomes a pain to deal with as he faces legal battles over another, mostly coming from former associates that are determined to make him fail.

Why do I believe The Social Network is overrated? Well, like most so-called biopics, the filmmakers would rather change the actual events of the story in favor of adding more "entertainment" to it, which explains why there's scenes of extreme drinking and partying that Zuckerberg claimed did not happen in real life. If Zuckerberg claimed these scenes did not happen in real life, then it truly is an insult to see something that did not happen be placed in a movie meant to tell the "true story." People, this is why I've bashed other biopics in the past, such as The Blind Side! It's a disgrace to the real story, and it questions the future of Hollywood filmmaking. But while The Blind Side suffered terribly due to its extremely inaccurate portrayal and racist stereotypes, The Social Network had better things to be recognized on, but it's still not a masterpiece.

Another problem that is suffered greatly in the film is the rather uneven direction from David Fincher, the so-called acclaimed filmmaker who made this movie. I haven't seen any of his other films, so I can't judge him when it comes to how great of a director he supposedly is, but his direction here is all over the place. The pacing is uneven and what messes up the flow is the fact that the whole story is told in flashback, with the story told in time of the legal battle. It really messes up moments in the film that could have been shocking, but because of it, it ends up becoming rather predictable. Take a look at the Eduardo character for example. The film starts out showing why he hates Zuckerberg so much and how he betrayed him in ownership of Facebook, then we go back in time to see them as buddies before the ultimate betrayal. This format of filmmaking has worked well in the past, working brilliantly in films like Titanic and Sunset Boulevard, but it doesn't hear.

But what makes up for the direction is its witty screenplay by Aaron Sorkin. Despite the inaccuracies of the film, I have to admit the script is pure genius. It's probably the biggest reason why many critics adored this film, cause it's just a modern work of art. The opening scene with Zuckerberg's love issue was executed brilliantly, and I was laughing my head off at the love gone bonkers! The sheer brilliance of the screenplay was so good that it raised my final score for the film a little bit than what I was initially going to give it (which would have been a 5).

Also making the film worth just one viewing is its very strong acting performances. Nominated for an Academy Award for his performance, Jesse Eisenburg nails the nerdy, intriguing persona of Mark Zuckerberg. I wouldn't have rooted for the character due to his selfish motivations, but I was impressed by what Eisenburg did in his acting. With the announcement that he's playing Lex Luther in the upcoming Batman/Superman crossover, I have no doubts that Eisenburg will be a shining light in the next generation of real, talented acting. I was also impressed with Justin Timberlake as the drug-addicting womanizer Napster founder Sean Parker. I'm not sure if the things depicted int he film were true or not, cause the drug abuse goes over-the-top towards the end of the film, Timberlake shows that he can go from pop sensation to actor in a decently entertaining performance. But the single-handed best performance of the whole entire film, and one I would truly give an award to, is Andrew Garfield as co-founder Eduardo Saverin. His final anger rant at the end of the film over his betrayal is worth an Oscar alone! I also wish well for Garfield's career, hopefully with better material when his Spider-Man contract is up.

But even with all my likings on the film, there's still one thing I need to really complain about, and that's the music score by Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross. IT IS POSSIBLY THE WORST MUSIC SCORE I'VE EVER HEARD IN MY LIFE! The heavy use of electronic synthesizers might have worked if the film was called "Social Network in Outer Space" or some other ridiculous B-Movie styled title, but in a film about the creator of Facebook it's extremely out of place. What makes me even more mad was that it won an Oscar, beating out the phenomenal scores of both John Powell's for How to Train Your Dragon and Hans Zimmer's for Inception! That I will never understand, even long after the day I die!

While The Social Network has a very witty screenplay and there's strong acting performances, especially from Andrew Garfield and Jesse Eisenberg, The Social Network is one of the most overrated Oscar-nominated films of recent memory. David Fincher's direction and storytelling is uneven and predictable, it lacks reasoning to why anyone would want to join Facebook (unless you're already a member, which I still have no interest in joining by the way), and the inaccuracy of the real story is a huge insult to Mark Zuckerberg and everyone involved in the actual creation of Facebook. There are far better biopics out there that strive to be honest, and they are much, much better, like Gandhi, Lincoln, and Captain Phillips. David Fincher is currently in talks in creating a Steve Jobs biopic, one that's supposed to make up for the critically panned Jobs movie with Ashton Kutcher, and all I have to say is, I sure hope he knows what he's doing.

 The Social Network is about how the much talked about social website,Facebook,came into existence and what really is the story behind it.For those who do not know about all the conflicts,and various other controversies,I really do not want to spoil the movie.From the trailer of this movie,you could tell that the movie is something very different.And I really cannot put into words how well made this movie really is.Jesse Eisenberg and Andrew Garfield as Mark Zuckerberg and Eduardo Saverin respectively  are probably the best choices.The supporting cast here are not given supporting roles-each and every character in the movie serve an important purpose.The movie is so well edited that if you miss even a minute,you could probably be missing on a very big plot point.David Fincher's work is so well done-I really don't think that there is even one single flaw with this movie!The movie has some really dark comedy at some points.

With a large, talented young cast and perfect script-writing at his disposal, director David Fincher has crafted an engaging and intimate look at one of the biggest and most profitable social experiments of our time.

Obviously, with the universal acclaim and success of this film, it is a 'good' film. And many people may just accept it flippantly without thinking twice about why it is so good. And there are many reasons why it is. Firstly, it is very clear that the filmmakers have made a very good job of keeping the film extremely close to the truth, at least, it would seem that way. And by making the film while Facebook is such a phenomenon, and Mr. Zuckerberg having so much power,  the film still portrays him in a slightly negative light, which is both a smart and brave move which has given the film the respect it justly deserves.

Brilliantly paced, directed, acted and written, The Social Network is not only an excellent interpretation of a true story, but one of the best movies in the last decade. Clear character motivation and a simple but hugely effective soundtrack make it riveting and powerful.

I appreciate 'The Social Network' for it's performances and stylisitc approach to the ever so popular websites growth... but the writing and line delivery is so dull at times, it makes this already methodically paced film ever so much more boring.

Making The Social Network was quite the risk. Facebook, while already massive and continuing to grow, is still young. The same could be said for its creators whom are portrayed in the film. It seemed strange to me to tackle the story of Facebook so soon. But shortly after viewing it, I was astounded. This is a beautifully crafted piece of cinema and one of the best films I have seen in my life. The cast is perfect. Jesse Eisenberg captures Mark Zuckerberg's cold genius wonderfully. Justin Timberlake is impressive as Sean Parker and is well on his way to making me forget acting wasn't his first job in show business. Andrew Garfield as Eduardo Saverin is quite possibly the best of them all. His "freak out" in the "One Million Members Party" scene is simultaneously shocking, heartbreaking, and mildly amusing, making it one of my favorite moments in all the movies I've seen. Of course, the actors are working off of a great script as well. The switching between the creation and the aftermath of Facebook is incredibly effective. My only gripe with The Social Network is the fact that Mark Zuckerberg and his associates (and enemies for that matter) have stated that a fair portion of the film is exaggeration. Part of me wanted the true story, but the rest of me remembers that it probably wouldn't have been nearly as entertaining. Regardless, I do not hesitate in the least when I say anyone who has experienced the rise of social media in any way needs to see this film. It is a movie that matters not only to our society of Facebookers and Tweeters, but also to the entire movie industry.
